@overpractised Make it Stick us a great resource for teachers to learn about a lot of these concepts. This experiment by Deslauriers et al (2019) is a good illustration: https://t.co/gQwgcNjQqa

@overpractised Students also think they are learning better during fluent learning experiences and think they are not learning as well during tasks that are cognitively challenging. Desirable difficulties—those that lead to deeper cognitive processing of the content—lead to better learning. 2/2

@overpractised Excellent thread! I would add two things: (1) illusions of knowing and (2) desirable difficulties. Students are not good at accurately assessing their own knowledge and often overestimate their abilities. This is where frequent low-stakes assessments can help. 1/2

@AKoenka @AcademicChatter This doesn't mean relaxing standards, either. You can still have a rigorous class that provides the flexibility to accommodate a variety of student needs and assets. The key is desirable difficulties.

@AKoenka @AcademicChatter Teaching in higher ed (or anywhere) is not about control, i.e. transmitting knowledge or playing arbitrary games w/ points or late work. It's about providing a safe space for students to explore and trust you to challenge them outside their comfort zone, helping them transform.

@cultofpedagogy Like it or not, students are consumers now. Learning needs to be relevant, not a power struggle or an excuse to check a box. UbD helps us get there. Even better: Creating Significant Learning Experiences by L. Dee Fink. It’s written for higher ed but perfectly applies to K12.

@cultofpedagogy At some point, they’ve all asked, why do we have to learn this?? They SHOULD ask this. Every lesson plan should begin with this. The big ideas and essential questions make it clear. The authentic assessment should be motivating so they WANT to learn the knowledge and skills.

@cultofpedagogy Yes, simple is better. They all have an experience of sitting in a class that was all about getting through a textbook and memorizing everything without really learning anything. That’s where I start. I ask, what would have been a better use of your time? Is there a better way?

@cultofpedagogy 5/ of K-12, esp with implementation of CCSS. It's still possible to marry these two worlds! Look for ID classes/programs in higher ed, particularly those that use ed tech as a strategy, and mind/brain/education which generally informs ID theory. I LOVE talking ID, so hit me up!

@cultofpedagogy 4/ is the closest thing K-12 has to instructional design. Don't be overwhelmed by the models. Once you read about them, they are mostly very intuitive. Primarily, the focus is on the learner, meaning making, and how learning happens versus content standards which is the focus...

@cultofpedagogy 3/ I teach ed tech to pre-service teachers and ID to grad students getting certified in ed tech. There is such a huge focus in most teacher prep programs on delivering content and managing behavior that the process of learning only gets cursory coverage. Understanding by Design..

@cultofpedagogy 2/ unlike the corporate world and to some degree online higher ed. The culture of K-12 is getting around to seeing the need for change, but it's like an ocean liner trying to change course and won't happen until there is more flexibility in scheduling, grouping, & testing.

@cultofpedagogy 1/ I discovered ID in my MEd program in instructional tech. The program was about transforming K-12 ed through technology & constructivism. K-12 was not--and is still mostly not--ready for this. They have a captive audience and are not invested in the success of EVERY child...
